Raloxifene doesn’t increase risk for endometrial Ca. ,but poses a higher risk for venous thromboembolism as compared to tamoxifen.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ampula The most common sites for an ectopic pregnancy are the ampullary (mid) portion of the fallopian tube (80-90%), isthmic (area closer to the uterus) portion of the fallopian tube (5-10%), fimbrial (distal end away from the uterus) portion of the fallopian tube (about 5%), cornual (within the uterine muscle) portion of the fallopian tube (1-2%), abdomen (1-2%), ovary (less than 1%), or cervix (less than 1%).

questions.text: Which of the following is treatment for Decubitus ulcers in Uterine Prolapse ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Packing Packing (along with manual repositioning of the uterus) Cause of decubitus ulcer:-Venous congestion When we push back the uterus, venous drainage improves and the ulcer heals Also we can do AG packing (Acridine glycerine)- This absorbs water, improves edema ∴ helps in faster healing.

questions.text: Epithelial lining of Fallopian tube is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Epithelial lining of fallopian tube is single layer ciliated columnar 1. We see secretary cells, ciliated cells and peg cells here. 2. Peg cells can convert into ciliated cells when required.

questions.text: Bartholin cyst is located on?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Major vestibular gland Major vestibular gland It is located b/w labia majora & labia minora (at the function of ant. 2/3rd and post 1/3rd) Duct opens b/w labia minora and hymen in vagina. Bartholin’s gland is lined by short columnar whereas duct is lined by transitional epithelium and the opening is lined by squamous epithelium ∴ all cancers can occur here. TOC= For symptomatic Bartholin’s- Incision & drainage For recc. Cyst-marsupialization

questions.text: A multiparous patient complains of dribbling of urine during coughing and laughing. She is having normal micturition as well. What is most likely?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Stress Incontinence Stress urinary in continence Involuntary escape of urine when intra-abdominal pressure is increased as in sneezing , coughing or laughing . Cause : A) Bladder neck descent B) Intrinsic sphincter defect Mechanism : Increase in intra-abdominal pressure > Compresses the upper Urethral (Continence) in normal conditions> But in bladder neck descent >Compression does not occur ( incontinence)

questions.text: Which of the following can cause Cervical Cancer
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) HPV 18 HPV6 & HPV11 cause condylomala accuminata and also laryngeal papillomatosis. m/c HPV for cervical cancer is HPV 16 (50% of all cancers) m/specific = HPV 18 HPV 16 +18 can cause 70% of cervical cancers. Vaccine • Made from L1 capsid protein • E6 & E7 are responsible for malignant transformation • E6 will knock out P53 gene • E7 will knock out RB gene HPV16 causes squamous cell ca. (site-transformation zone) HPV18 causes adenocarcinoma (site-endo cervix)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Erythromycin is not typically used to treat bacterial vaginosis (BV). The first-line treatments for BV are metronidazole and tinidazole, which are both effective against the anaerobic bacteria that are commonly involved in BV. Here’s why the other drugs are used: A. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is commonly used for BV, either in oral or vaginal cream form. C. Metronidazole: This is the first-line treatment for BV, often prescribed as an oral medication or vaginal gel. D. Tinidazole: Tinidazole is also an effective alternative to metronidazole for BV treatment.

An adolescent female presents with delayed puberty with primary amenorrhea with short stature on further evaluation she is found to have absence of Y chromosome but the presence of X chromosome in karyotyping. which of the following is also seen in this condition ?
What is the gold standard Investigation of endometriosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Histopathexamination Histopathological examination is considered the definitive "gold standard" for confirming endometriosis. While laparoscopy allows a surgeon to visually identify lesions suspected to be endometriosis, visual identification alone is not always 100?curate, as other conditions can mimic its appearance. The only way to definitively confirm the presence of endometriosis (endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterus) is through microscopic examination of tissue obtained via biopsy. Therefore, the histopathological report provides the irrefutable evidence required for a conclusive diagnosis.

A woman has been diagnosed with following Uterine anomaly. This pathology happens due to problem of which duct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Para mesonephric duct The paramesonephric duct, also known as the Mullerian duct, is responsible for giving rise to the female internal genitalia. Anomalies in its development can lead to conditions like a unicornuate uterus, where one duct develops normally while the other is rudimentary. The mesonephric duct (or Wolffian duct) forms the male internal genitalia, which include the seminal vesicles, ejaculatory ducts, epididymis, and ductus deferens. The urogenital sinus is involved in the formation of the external genitalia and the lower two-thirds of the vagina. Other uterine anomalies mentioned include: Normal uterus: Characterized by no dip in the fundus. Didelphys uterus: Both ducts develop separately, each having its own cervix, often associated with a double vagina or vaginal septum. Arcuate uterus: Appears normal externally with no dip but has a small dip inside the cavity; it usually does not affect obstetric or gynecological outcomes and is considered an embryological variant. Unicornuate uterus: Often seen on hysterosalpingography (HSG) as a banana-shaped uterus deviated to one side. It is associated with conditions like ectopic pregnancy and ectopic ovary. Bicornuate uterus: Features only one cervix and a deep dip in the external contour. Septate uterus: Has an absolutely normal external contour but contains a septum, leading to two cavities and usually one cervix.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has developed breast development and pubic hair. The mother wants to know which sign of puberty will typically occur next. Which of the following is the most likely next sign?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Peak height The first sign of puberty, though not visibly obvious, is the *growth spurt*, which is the initial acceleration of growth. The first visible sign of puberty in girls is thelarche (development of breast tissue). This is followed by pubarche (development of pubic hair). Next in sequence is peak height velocity, which is a sudden or maximum increase in the girl's height. Finally, menarche (the first menstrual period) occurs. For boys, the first sign of puberty is testicular enlargement, followed by penile enlargement, then pubarche, and eventually maximum height, which typically occurs later than in girls.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has been raised as a girl, has not developed breast tissue, and ultrasound reveals absence of the uterus. Karyotyping shows a 46,XY chromosomal pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 17-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency: This condition aligns with the description of primary amenorrhea, absent breast tissue, absent uterus, and a 46, XY karyotype. Gonadectomy is not performed. This specific enzyme deficiency is known to cause abnormal sexual development primarily in 46, XY (male) individuals, rather than 46, XX (female). In 46, XX females, the most common enzyme deficiencies causing abnormal sexual development are 21-hydroxylase (associated with hyponatremia and hypotension) and 11-hydroxylase (associated with hypertension).

questions.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are protective against all of the following cancers except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cervical cancer OCPs are known to reduce the risk of: Endometrial cancer Colorectal cancer Ovarian cancer Reduction in blood loss, helping to regulate cycles (beneficial for women with PCOS) Decreased pain (useful in dysmenorrhea or endometriosis) Reduced fibroids (due to decreased blood loss) Reduced formation of ovarian cysts Lower incidence of benign breast disease Conversely, OCPs are associated with an *increased risk* of: Cervical cancer Breast cancer Hepatic adenoma OCPs are also considered the drug of choice for managing hirsutism and acne.

questions.text: A 36-year-old P2L2 patient diagnosed with severe endometriosis shows pelvic adhesions on laparoscopy. She has undergone tubal ligation and adhesiolysis previously. What is the most appropriate management during laparoscopy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Total Laproscopic hysterectomy For severe, recurrent endometriosis that has persisted after previous medical and/or surgical management, especially when the patient's family is complete, hysterectomy is considered the last resort. This is because the endometrial tissue causing the condition originates from the uterus. Routine salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of ovaries) is generally not recommended* for women under 50, as it induces menopause and can cause other health problems, unless there is a specific request from the patient. Medical management (e.g., GnRH agonists) or repeat adhesiolysis might be considered for less severe cases, or if fertility is still desired, but not as the definitive long-term solution for severe recurrent disease in a patient who has completed her family.

questions.text: What is a co-test in cervical cancer screening?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HPV+PAPS The co-test" for cervical cancer screening is a combination of HPV testing and Pap smear. In resource-rich countries (e.g., the US), the recommended interval for the co-test is 5-yearly. The Pap smear offers higher specificity, while HPV DNA testing provides higher sensitivity, making their combination a highly effective screening tool. According to WHO guidelines for resource-limited countries: Screening should ideally begin at 30 years of age. The best recommended method, if feasible, is HPV testing (5-10 yearly interval). The second-best method is VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid), with a 3-yearly interval. Pap smear also has a 3-yearly interval in these settings. Screening typically stops at 50 years of age. VIA is considered the most cost-effective screening method

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) safe according to MEC1?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) HIV infection The MEC categories classify the appropriateness of contraceptive methods: MEC 1: The method can be used with no restrictions. MEC 2: The benefits outweigh the risks. MEC 3: The risks generally outweigh the benefits, meaning the method is not usually recommended unless other methods are unavailable or unacceptable. MEC 4: Represents an absolute contraindication, meaning the method should not be used. OCPs are considered safe (MEC 1) for individuals with HIV. Conditions like uncontrolled diabetes and uncontrolled hypertension are typically considered restrictions or contraindications (MEC 3 or 4) for OCPs. Hyperlipidemia is also a condition where OCPs are generally not the preferred or recommended agent.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindication to subcutaneous implant/iud?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Undiagnosed genital bleeding For both subcutaneous implants (which are progesterone-containing devices) and IUDs, undiagnosed bleeding is a contraindication. While OCPs might be contraindicated in cases of hypertension, progesterone-only compounds (like implants) and IUDs can generally be given to patients with hypertension. Similarly, for diabetes, only progesterone-only devices or IUDs can typically be given, whereas OCPs might be contraindicated. A history of past Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is generally not a contraindication* for IUDs; only current PID is a contraindication. Other contraindications for IUDs include suspected pregnancy, uterine abnormalities (especially where the cavity is distorted, e.g., by fibroids or Mullerian anomalies), current pelvic infection of any type, Wilson's disease (specifically for copper IUDs), and breast cancer (specifically for Mirena, a progesterone-releasing IUD).

choices.text: Gold standard for diagnosis is hysteroscopy
If biopsy is done, no further follow-up is required
In recurrent symptoms, no biopsy is required

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding endometrial hyperplasia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) D&C is used for diagnosis Dilation and Curettage (D&C) or fractional curettage is the gold standard for the diagnosis of endometrial hyperplasia, particularly when there is a risk of atypia, when an inadequate tissue sample is obtained, or if the cervix is stenosed. While hysteroscopy can be combined with D&C, the D&C/fractional curettage is more crucial for diffuse conditions like hyperplasia.

questions.text: A patient develops secondary amenorrhea for 9 months after D&C. Both progesterone challenge test and estrogen-progesterone challenge test are negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Asherman's syndrome The history of a D&C procedure followed by secondary amenorrhea, coupled with negative Progesterone Challenge Test (PCT) and Estrogen + Progesterone (E+P) Challenge Test (indicating no bleeding even after external hormone administration), strongly suggests an issue within the uterus itself that prevents endometrial response. This clinical picture is highly indicative of Asherman's syndrome, which is characterized by intrauterine adhesions, often developing after uterine instrumentation like D&C. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) in Asherman's syndrome typically shows multiple small, irregular filling defects within the uterus.

questions.text: Marked structure 3 & 6 in a diagram, and the hormone responsible for their growth is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Estrogen and progesterone Estrogen is primarily required for the growth and development of the ducts within the breast Progesterone is primarily required for the growth and development of the lobules Oxytocin is the milk ejection hormone, responsible for causing the contraction of myoepithelial cells to release milk; it is not directly involved in the development or growth of breast structures. Prolactin is the milk formation hormone, essential for lactation, but not directly for the initial structural development of ducts and lobules.

questions.text: What is the fixative used for Pap smear preparation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 95% ethanol The most common fixative used for Pap smear slides is 95% ethyl alcohol (ethanol). Sometimes, a combination of 95% ethanol and 5% ether is also employed. It is critical to avoid air drying the slide during preparation. The sample for a Pap smear is typically collected from the transformation zone using a device like an Ayre spatula.

questions.text: Identify this shown finding:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Teratoma The presence of hair and teeth within an ovarian tumor is a classic characteristic of a dermoid cyst, which is also known as a mature cystic teratoma. A mature cystic teratoma is classified as a germ cell tumor. It is notable for being: The most common germ cell tumor. The most common ovarian tumor in reproductive age. The most common ovarian tumor during pregnancy. The most common ovarian tumor to undergo torsion. While primarily unilateral, it can be bilateral in up to 10% of cases.

questions.text: In hypothalamic hamartoma what is increased
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gnrh Hypothalamic hamartoma is a recognized cause of precocious puberty. It is, in fact, the most common brain tumor to cause this condition. It leads to central precocious puberty, which involves the premature activation of the hypothalamus. When the hypothalamus is prematurely activated, levels of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) are increased. While central precocious puberty is most often idiopathic (90% of cases), in about 10% of girls, it can be due to a brain tumor. Therefore, an MRI of the brain should be performed in cases of precocious puberty to rule out tumors such as pinealoma, glioma, or meningioma.

questions.text: Vagina is close to anus but infection protection is there how?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Perineal structures The primary reason for protection against infection from the anal canal is the presence of perineal tissue between the vaginal opening and the anal opening. This tissue acts as a physical barrier, preventing the direct spread of infection into the vagina
